Am I missing anything?
```
root@ubuntu:~/quiche# git log
commit 70d6d3e233568e906e66179a56c93cf9b0616899 (HEAD, tag: 0.24.4)
Author: Alessandro Ghedini <alessandro@ghedini.me>
Date:   Tue Jun 17 15:52:36 2025 +0100

    quiche: release 0.24.4

commit d796e1b9e62f2f7cc9180611d234e2dffa1db524
Author: Apoorv Kothari <akothari@cloudflare.com>
Date:   Wed Apr 23 15:23:30 2025 -0700

    prevent an optimistic ack attack by skipping packets

    As per the RFC's recommends, this PR adds mechanisms to periodically
    skip packets on send in order to track a mis-behaving peer and prevent
    an Optimistic ACK attack.

commit a376c9b47525921e2f598b398f8d2de1a0d8f78a
Author: Apoorv Kothari <akothari@cloudflare.com>
Date:   Fri Apr 18 11:11:09 2025 -0700

    validate ack ranges and implement RFC recommendation

    This change adds validation for ACK ranges received from the peer. It
    also closes the connection with a PROTOCOL_VIOLATION error as per the
    RFC's recommendation:

    > An endpoint SHOULD treat receipt of an acknowledgment for a packet it
    > did not send as a connection error of type PROTOCOL_VIOLATION

    Fixes CVE-2025-4821.
```

I added ```#include "../url.h"``` to ```lib/vquic/curl_quiche.c``` and it worked.
Are we missing anything here?
Just found the same and made https://github.com/curl/curl/pull/17858. I have no idea how that went past our CI checks. Maybe the merge failed? /cc @bagder
The downside of doing so many "unity" builds in CI when most users and developers don't...
Should we gang up on @vszakats to reduce this a bit? At least for the singular feature builds.

Linux CMake builds seem like the best candidates to switch to non-unity,
without losing much build perf. Tests are also no longer affected by turning
it off, so there is no loss there.

A unity-friendly way to tackle this, would be making internal headers less
granular, by having something similar to `curl/curl.h`, but for internals. It
can be an umbrella header that includes headers used from most sources
anyway. `url.h` would likely fall into this category.

That said, it will remain nearly impossible to catch every PP-related issue in
CI. Subjectively this particular fallout don't seem like a strong enough
trigger to switch things to non-unity: It's a nicher backend and this kind of
fallout is rare.

But, certainly something to keep in mind.

While I appreciate the build performance with unity, it is unfortunate when broken changes pass our CI and hit our users. 

The "big beautiful" internal header file is not a good idea for maintainability of code. I worked hard during the last years to remove code parts from the large headers that we have, giving protocols and features a more "local" visibility. This makes them easier to understand.

What I had in mind is rather to have a header file that includes commonly used
headers e.g. `url.h`, `strdup.h`, `curl_printf.h`, or even `curl_memory.h` and
`memdebug.h` to avoid having to think about this for most cases, and reduce
mistakes by default.

This while keeping individual headers granular and maintainable.

Missing a header may also cause issues without any compiler warning. E.g.
missing `memdebug.h` in Rustls, fixed just recently. There were quite a few other
subtle bugs fixed in the recent years resulting from macro discrepancies when
compiling individual sources, that ended up configuring the same thing differently
in these separate sources. Unity builds helped finding these.

Haven't looked at this in detail yet for `lib`, but my impression is that simplifying
the header inclusion tree may be something useful for the codebase. There are
duplicates, and possibly quite many redundant/unused includes too.
